criteria: Application of Safe Food Handling Techniques
descriptions: No attempt to demonstrate safe food handling; practices are clearly unsafe and could lead to contamination.
Demonstrates minimal awareness of safe food handling; some practices are unsafe or incorrect.
Shows basic safe food handling practices, but inconsistently; some areas need improvement.
Consistently applies most safe food handling techniques correctly; minor errors may occur.
Demonstrates excellent safe food handling techniques; only very minor oversights are present.
Exemplary application of safe food handling techniques throughout the preparation process; models best practices.
No understanding of cross-contamination prevention; clearly contaminates different food groups.
Shows limited understanding of cross-contamination; may use same cutting board for raw meat and vegetables without cleaning.
Attempts to prevent cross-contamination, but some practices are inadequate or incorrect.
Generally prevents cross-contamination through proper hand washing and separating raw and cooked foods; may have occasional lapses.
Effectively prevents cross-contamination by consistently using separate cutting boards, utensils, and proper hand washing techniques.
Implements rigorous cross-contamination prevention strategies, showing a comprehensive understanding of food safety.
No awareness of proper cooking or storage temperatures; food is likely undercooked or stored improperly.
Shows limited awareness of proper cooking or storage temperatures; guesses temperatures or times.
Can identify some proper cooking and storage temperatures, but may not apply them correctly.
Generally adheres to proper cooking and storage temperatures using a thermometer; may need some reminders.
Consistently monitors and maintains proper cooking and storage temperatures to ensure food safety.
Demonstrates expert knowledge of temperature control, ensuring all foods are cooked and stored at safe temperatures to prevent bacterial growth.
